transcripts.text: Hebrew has been probably the best thing I've done at Brown.
Being at Brown and learning Hebrew has been incredible.
I chose to take the 100 class because while I have some sort of background in it, I didn't have a really strong grammatical foundation.
I came in in 300, so I did 300 through 600. and the professor really ensures that you learn a lot in the course individually.
She knows all of the very strategic ways to teach Hebrew, and you get to a conversational level very quickly, and she really throws you in.

I have only been in classes here where it's total immersion.  I think that that really pushed me a lot, but also I learned so much better because of it, and I'm really grateful that that's how Brown's languages work.

I just came back from a semester abroad in Israel this past semester.  I was at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem so that I really got to put my skills to use and speak Hebrew actually in a Hebrew speaking environment which was really awesome and I took Hebrew there and a one month immersion class.  So learning Hebrew at Brown really helped me be prepared for that semester.

Then I went to Jerusalem last semester.  I direct enrolled in Hebrew University through our study abroad office.  And I was just taking Hebrew and Arabic, living in Israel, Palestine, talking to a lot of Israelis and Palestinians in their native language, which was super, super cool.

And I'm participating this year in a new fellowship through the Swearer Center for Public Service.  That's an exchange program, which is bringing six Israeli and Palestinian students to Brown in the fall, and then Brown students to Hebrew University in Jerusalem in the spring to create a really multicultural group of people to study the same issues.  So I'm really looking forward to the opportunities that will give me to practice my Hebrew and my Arabic outside of the classroom.
You learn so much so quickly.  And it's just been a huge part of my experience at Brown and definitely a class I look forward to every semester.
If you're considering taking Hebrew, you should do it.  If you're not considering taking Hebrew, you should also do it.
